name: Black Stork
description: Slightly smaller than the white stork, it has predominantly black plumage with a metallic sheen. Its belly is white, beak and legs red. Chicks hatch with a white downy coat and a black beak.
spread_note: Breeds in Central and Eastern Europe, Portugal, Spain, and India; winters in Sub-Saharan Africa and China.
food_note: Small vertebrates including fish, larger invertebrates
image_alt: Black stork, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 73.5–75 cm; tail length 21.5–25 cm; wingspan 145–155 cm; weight 2.6–3.6 kg
reproduction: Females lay 3–6 eggs; incubation lasts 31–33 days.
attractions: It lives discreetly, often escaping notice despite its size. For nesting, it seeks extensive forests, building a wide twig nest high in tree crowns. The male stays with the female throughout the nesting period, though pairs are usually not permanent. Both parents take turns incubating the eggs and feeding the chicks.
breeding: A single black stork was kept at the zoo in 1934. In the 1950s, many passed through Prague Zoo as part of transits to Western Europe, some staying for years. From the mid-1970s to 1992, there was a break in breeding, but since then, we have kept black storks continuously. The first chicks were raised in 1995.
